rsbNotes.title: Ps 47
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 47 Along with Ps. 93 and 95–99, this psalm can be classified as a kingship psalm. The image of God’s enthronement is at the heart of the psalm. The occasion is a great military victory, and God is King, not only of Israel, but of the universe. This prayer also properly celebrates the ascension and rule of Jesus Christ. Jesus is both King and Warrior (Luke 19:38; 23:38; John 1:49).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 47:1
rsbNotes.text: 47:1 all peoples. Since God is King of all the earth, and not just Israel, all the nations are called to join in the praise.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 47:2
rsbNotes.text: 47:2 king over all the earth. See “God Reigns: Divine Sovereignty” at Dan. 4:34.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 47:3
rsbNotes.text: 47:3 He subdued peoples. God won innumerable victories for His people throughout their history, beginning with the great victory at the Red Sea (Ex. 15).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 47:4
rsbNotes.text: 47:4 our heritage. This refers to the conquest and allotment of the Promised Land. Deut. 7:1–11 explains that it is only through God’s grace that Israel possessed the land.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 47:5
rsbNotes.text: 47:5 has gone up. This is an enthronement. God has been King from all eternity (Ps. 93:2), but after the victory His kingship is celebrated anew.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 47:9
rsbNotes.text: 47:9 The princes. These leaders should gather today; they will gather tomorrow when Christ returns.
